Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I'm still worried about convert.py.  With no -f option, qemu-img attempts to infer the image format, which I imagine would mean doing something like whatever it does to process the qemu-img info call.  Looks like there are a few things we could do here:

(1) make a qemu-img info call with the proc restrictions, and if it fails, don't attempt the conversion

(2) add a config option to allow the proc limits to be specified, with some kind of reasonable default (though I have no idea what that default would be)

(3) do nothing, just emphasize in the release note that tasks (particularly the conversion and introspection tasks) should only be exposed to trusted users

Thoughts?

Patch Set 3:

> I'm still worried about convert.py.  With no -f option, qemu-img
 > attempts to infer the image format, which I imagine would mean
 > doing something like whatever it does to process the qemu-img info
 > call.  Looks like there are a few things we could do here:
 > 
 > (1) make a qemu-img info call with the proc restrictions, and if it
 > fails, don't attempt the conversion
 > 
 > (2) add a config option to allow the proc limits to be specified,
 > with some kind of reasonable default (though I have no idea what
 > that default would be)
 > 
 > (3) do nothing, just emphasize in the release note that tasks
 > (particularly the conversion and introspection tasks) should only
 > be exposed to trusted users
 > 
 > Thoughts?

That's a valid concern. We can validate by reproducing the info attack with convert. Let me work on that.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Patch Set 3:

> I'm still worried about convert.py.  With no -f option, qemu-img
 > attempts to infer the image format, which I imagine would mean
 > doing something like whatever it does to process the qemu-img info
 > call.  Looks like there are a few things we could do here:
 > 
 > (1) make a qemu-img info call with the proc restrictions, and if it
 > fails, don't attempt the conversion

If the method is crafted out to a common place and we handle the right exceptions or add more if..then..else clauses, we will avoid such slips.

 > 
 > (2) add a config option to allow the proc limits to be specified,
 > with some kind of reasonable default (though I have no idea what
 > that default would be)

We've agreed to be conservative about adding configs especially for tasks. I think if operator want some different setup they are welcome to add more or different flows to this default setup.

 > 
 > (3) do nothing, just emphasize in the release note that tasks
 > (particularly the conversion and introspection tasks) should only
 > be exposed to trusted users

This can be an option as the tasks api is admin only by default and glance team wants to advertise so. (right?)

 > 
 > Thoughts?

Patch Set 3:

Re: pulling the method out to a common place, let's please keep the refactoring as *minimal* as possible in this review so it's suitable for backports to stable branches. If this introduces too much refactoring it might not qualify and we might be stranding folks on stable branches.

Patch Set 3:

Answering Nikhil's points out-of-order:

> We've agreed to be conservative about adding configs especially for tasks. I think if operator want some different setup they are welcome to add more or different flows to this default setup.

Good point, let's not add any options now.

> > do nothing just emphasize in the release note that tasks should only be exposed to trusted users
> This can be an option as the tasks api is admin only by default and glance team wants to advertise so. (right?)

I agree, and think it's the way to go.  Plus, it is consistent with our position over the past few cycles.

> If the method is crafted out to a common place and we handle the right exceptions or add more if..then..else clauses, we will avoid such slips.

I'm thinking we'll need to refactor the tasks workflow in Pike (possibly in Ocata, depending on how import develops).  I think we need a "sanitize" step in the flow that's completely independent of the other tasks, and any flow that handles end-user-supplied data, first pumps it through the "sanitize" task.  Then the downstream tasks won't have to worry about this kind of thing (hopefully).  We can figure out the best way to do this on the Pike spec.

So I agree with Ian here that let's not refactor too much at the moment so this fix can be easily backported.

 > the other tasks, and any flow that handles end-user-supplied data,
 > first pumps it through the "sanitize" task.  Then the downstream
 > tasks won't have to worry about this kind of thing (hopefully).  We
 > can figure out the best way to do this on the Pike spec.

+1

 > 
 > So I agree with Ian here that let's not refactor too much at the
 > moment so this fix can be easily backported.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

As Daniel points out on the bug [1], Brian is correct that we need -f to be provided otherwise these qemu-img commands *will* try to guess the format and that will be a problem.

I'm also unconvinced we can refactor the exception handling and command usage into one place like Nikhil wants after looking more closely at the usage in both places.

One exception block checks the errno value which Flavio wrote to handle a missing executable (I assume qemu-img) while the other just logs the message and reraises it for any exception.

What we could do, is safely take the bit that looks like

    putils.trycmd('qemu-img', 'info', ...)

Into a separate function and work on refactoring the error handling in Ocata in a follow-on patch if we *really* want it to be that concise in these places.

This will mean that we'll have an qemu-img-info command that does the correct thing (uses -f) and takes the parameters necessary to work. Let's also start with the most minimal definition of that common method. We can put it in glance.async.utils if everyone agrees.

[1]: https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1449062/comments/73

Patch Set 3:

> As Daniel points out on the bug [1], Brian is correct that we need
 > -f to be provided otherwise these qemu-img commands *will* try to
 > guess the format and that will be a problem.
 > 
 > I'm also unconvinced we can refactor the exception handling and
 > command usage into one place like Nikhil wants after looking more
 > closely at the usage in both places.
 > 
 > One exception block checks the errno value which Flavio wrote to
 > handle a missing executable (I assume qemu-img) while the other
 > just logs the message and reraises it for any exception.
 > 
 > What we could do, is safely take the bit that looks like
 > 
 > putils.trycmd('qemu-img', 'info', ...)
 > 
 > Into a separate function and work on refactoring the error handling
 > in Ocata in a follow-on patch if we *really* want it to be that
 > concise in these places.
 > 
 > This will mean that we'll have an qemu-img-info command that does
 > the correct thing (uses -f) and takes the parameters necessary to
 > work. Let's also start with the most minimal definition of that
 > common method. We can put it in glance.async.utils if everyone
 > agrees.
 > 
 > [1]: https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1449062/comments/73

I really don't think any refactoring is required right away in the context of this bug. We can figure that out in Ocata like you said.

Also, the "qemu-img info" doesn't need the "-f" parameter. It is guarded by the process limit anyway. We have to use  the "-f" parameter only for "qemu-img convert" to avoid the inferring. 

Is that assessment accurate?
Uploaded patch set 4.
